thread.title: Grant Kerr of Jetstar in Palmerston North
thread.title_full: Grant Kerr of Jetstar in Palmerston North

author: Susan Teodoro
title: Grant Kerr of Jetstar in Palmerston North
text:
Grant Kerr of Jetstar in Palmerston North SUSAN TEODORO Last updated 19:14, July 1 2015 David Unwin/ Fairfax NZ 
Jetstar New Zealand Head Grant Kerr visits Palmerston North. 
Jetstar is drumming up support in regional centres but won't be drawn on the chances of the airline coming to Palmerston North. 
Jetstar New Zealand head Grant Kerr said the decision depended on factors such as the likelihood of future growth. 
"It's difficult to say at this point until we get the opportunity to visit all of the regions," he said. 
"We have not got our destinations chosen yet. 
"We believe that there is potential for growth in this region, but we want to understand how much growth and over what period of time." 
The airline wanted to make sure growth was sustainable. 
Kerr attended a regional roadshow meeting in Palmerston North on Wednesday. 
"It's great to see the support we're getting," he said. 
About 120 leaders from the region attended lunch at Hotel Coachman to hear Kerr speak and ask him questions about Jetstar and its expectations. 
Kerr has been impressed by intense competition on social media to attract Jetstar and said it would play a part in the final decision. Ad Feedback 
"The social media campaign has been sensational. We will be keeping a close eye on that and it will be taken into our considerations," he said. 
National list MP Jono Naylor set up the popular Jetstar to Palmerston North Facebook page, which has over 11,000 likes. 
Naylor has also championed an online survey. 
"The Jetstar to Palmerston North survey had over 1000 responses, which shows strong local support for including Palmerston North in Jetstar's regional expansion," he said. 
Rival Facebook page Bring Jetstar to Taranaki has over 12,000 likes. 
Kerr said Jetstar had a tight time frame and a decision was expected in early September. 
Palmerston North Mayor Grant Smith described the meeting as positive and said he rated the city's chances. 
"This is the biggest turnout they've had," he said. 
"I think we tick a lot of the boxes. 
"Our infrastructure is already set up so we're ready to go." 
Manawatu Chamber of Commerce chief executive Stephanie Gundersen-Reid also said the meeting had been a success. 
The airline will choose four centres to fly from from a shortlist of seven, including Palmerston North. - Stuff
